quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Think of SEO as a product.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Reframes SEO from a marketing tactic into a product discipline, implying PM-style thinking and ownership.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The product managers are the people that should be thinking about this SEO question because it's a product question.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Assigns clear organizational ownership for SEO strategy in the AI era, challenging the default “SEO belongs to marketing” assumption.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If you can't answer the question about what is it that someone's going to do a search on, then don't do SEO.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A blunt go/no-go criterion that forces teams to validate search intent before investing in SEO work.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Up until AI Overviews, whoever won on that long form piece of content would get that first click. But now that doesn't exist anymore.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Captures the core shift caused by AI answers: traditional “rank #1 and get the click” dynamics are breaking down.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: the tactics around SEO haven't really changed. It's always been the exact same thing.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Counterintuitively argues that while the surface experience is changing (AI answers), the underlying SEO playbook remains stable.

quotes.topic_title: Why AI forces a rethink of SEO
quotes.text: I really like what's happening with AI in general for SEO because it's causing everyone that cares about SEO traffic, whether that's a PM or that's a CMO or that's a CEO, to really be forced into pivoting their thinking about what SEO traffic means because the tactics around SEO haven't really changed.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Highlights the core shift: AI is changing how leaders must define and value SEO traffic, even if tactics look similar.

quotes.topic_title: Why AI forces a rethink of SEO
quotes.text: It's always been the exact same thing.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A blunt, memorable critique that challenges the assumption that SEO has been rapidly evolving pre-AI.

quotes.topic_title: Why AI forces a rethink of SEO
quotes.text: So essentially what you're telling me is I need to find my keywords, put that into content, and then build some links. Is there anything else you're going to do for me? Why should I pay you?
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A concrete example of how traditional SEO can sound commoditized, forcing practitioners to articulate business value beyond tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Why AI forces a rethink of SEO
quotes.text: And LLMs and AI in general is forcing people to think again, how should SEO work? How should I be driving business from the search channel?
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Reframes the practitioner’s job from executing SEO mechanics to designing how search drives business outcomes in an AI era.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: First, Pendo is built around product analytics, seeing what your users are actually doing in your apps so that you can optimize their experience.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical reminder to ground product decisions in observed user behavior via analytics to drive experience optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Next, Pendo lets you deploy in-app guides that lead users through the actions that matter most.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable tactic—using in-app guidance—to steer users toward key behaviors and activation moments.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I'm not surprised at all that over 10,000 companies use it today.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete adoption data point that signals broad market validation and maturity of the platform category.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It fights bias and SEO spam.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A pointed, contrarian positioning statement that challenges the assumption that mainstream search results are neutral and high-quality.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So essentially Google and other tech companies had their hand forced by OpenAI and ChatGPT.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Frames the AI-search shift as a competitive forcing function, useful for practitioners tracking why search platforms are changing behavior and incentives.

quotes.topic_title: How Google AI Overviews came to be
quotes.text: However, Google was worried about it, and I think one of Google's primary stakeholders is really Wall Street. So if Wall Street suddenly thinks that Google is a has-been company and they're not interesting anymore and they don't want to maintain investments in them, their stock price goes down. And that hurts Google's ability to recruit employees. It hurts Google's ability to raise money and invest in all the interesting stuff they do.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A useful mental model for predicting Google’s product moves: investor perception can be as decisive as user needs.

quotes.topic_title: How Google AI Overviews came to be
quotes.text: And there were huge issues with what they were doing there because there's monetization issues. Everything they do comes from ads. The majority of their revenue comes from ads. So if you're going to show this AI answer on a search result, then you also can't have ads. You need to go all in on one of them. That was one issue which they actually have not solved yet. Another issue they had was liability.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Highlights the core constraint practitioners should plan around: AI answers collide with Google’s ad model and legal risk.

quotes.topic_title: How Google AI Overviews came to be
quotes.text: And the third issue there, which is another liability concern, is it plagiarism?
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Points to a durable risk factor for AI search that can shape how content is sourced, credited, and surfaced.

quotes.topic_title: How Google AI Overviews came to be
quotes.text: So they took about a year to test this thing, which was fascinating because we're tech people and most of the listeners are tech people. Google is very much a launch fast kind of company. They reveal something and then it sort of rolls out very, very quickly.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A counterintuitive signal: when Google slows down, it often indicates unusually hard monetization/liability problems behind the scenes.

quotes.topic_title: How Google AI Overviews came to be
quotes.text: To maybe help people understand why this may impact SEO, if it's not obvious, is it pushes results down. People get the answer right there. They don't have to click your links. And then there's also the sponsored links at the top of the page that already are pushing you down. So basically your stuff is harder and harder to find, right?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical takeaway for SEO strategy: expect reduced clicks as answers and ads compress organic visibility.

quotes.topic_title: Top-of-funnel discovery gets swallowed by AI
quotes.text: Actually, it's not that it's harder to find, your stuff becomes less relevant.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Reframes the AI/ads impact on SEO from a ranking/visibility problem to a relevance problem, changing what practitioners should optimize for.

quotes.topic_title: Top-of-funnel discovery gets swallowed by AI
quotes.text: So the reason why I think this disruption is so big is because the journey changes, the discovery changes.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Offers a mental model: AI shifts the user journey by absorbing top-of-funnel discovery, forcing SEO strategy to adapt to new funnel stages.

quotes.topic_title: Top-of-funnel discovery gets swallowed by AI
quotes.text: And now you're in the mid-funnel and that's where SEO begins to matter.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on where to focus: prioritize mid-funnel queries and content where users move from AI direction to deeper evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Top-of-funnel discovery gets swallowed by AI
quotes.text: So whereas before if you were a travel site and you were able to rank on best beach vacation within two hours of the United States, that's your ranking result. And then you have your long piece of content and you have your ads and you can monetize that.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Concrete example of the old SEO monetization playbook built on top-of-funnel rankings and long-form content.

quotes.topic_title: Top-of-funnel discovery gets swallowed by AI
quotes.text: That all changes when you can still rank number one on that, but you're all the way at the bottom of the page.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Highlights the practical consequence of AI Overviews: even #1 rankings can lose value if discovery is satisfied before the click.

quotes.topic_title: Early impact: not apocalypse yet, but coming
quotes.text: So prior to the last couple weeks, it was not available on logged out search. It was only on logged in search. And even more than that, on that logged in search, Google had rolled it back significantly because of those embarrassing things that happened in May and June when they first launched it. They're only just now launching it broader. And I do think we're going to see impacts.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Explains why many sites haven’t yet seen major traffic changes: limited availability and prior rollbacks delayed real-world impact.

quotes.topic_title: Early impact: not apocalypse yet, but coming
quotes.text: Of course, another challenge with pinpointing and impacts is they're rolling algorithm updates that are happening, which we'll also talk about, and that will mask what's happening. Because if you've been hit by an algo update and suddenly you recover from the algo update, you'll see more traffic, but you might have seen more traffic but on a lower base because these AI Overviews are changing things.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Gives a practical measurement warning: algorithm updates can hide AI Overview effects, so practitioners should interpret traffic changes relative to a shifting baseline.

quotes.topic_title: Early impact: not apocalypse yet, but coming
quotes.text: And I think the riding line is the journey. We're in the funnel that user is.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Introduces a funnel/journey framework for predicting where AI Overviews will disrupt clicks most.

quotes.topic_title: Early impact: not apocalypse yet, but coming
quotes.text: So if you are WebMD and you're writing content about the human body, just generic content that has existed since medical journals were created, AI Overviews are going to be fantastic at giving you that answer.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Identifies a high-risk content category: generic informational queries where AI can synthesize answers without sending users to publishers.

quotes.topic_title: Early impact: not apocalypse yet, but coming
quotes.text: I used to have a website called whenishanukkahthisyear.com, because it changes every year and it's just the date. That was the whole website. It gives you the date of Hanukkah this year. And I put ads on there and made 10 bucks a year, and then Google came in and just gave you freaking answers right inside the search result. So I've experienced this.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of “zero-click” behavior: simple-answer sites can be wiped out when Google answers directly in SERPs.

quotes.topic_title: Structured vs unstructured answers and SEO disruption
quotes.text: What's happening now is Google's taking this unstructured data from content and building it into structured data.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Defines the core mechanism of the new SEO disruption: turning previously monetizable content into directly answerable data.

quotes.topic_title: Structured vs unstructured answers and SEO disruption
quotes.text: And again, instead of reading all that content and making a decision, Google could take all that unstructured data, not just Google, again, ChatGPT or Claude can take all that unstructured data, and give you a statistic based on everything they've read.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Explains how LLM-style summarization changes user behavior by collapsing research into an instant synthesized answer.

quotes.topic_title: Structured vs unstructured answers and SEO disruption
quotes.text: And then a user might find out there's another piece of information where I'd actually like to read a medical paper, or that now I'd like to Google and find the closest doctor to me who has certain hours. That's a Google search. That's not an LLM AI search.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Gives a practical boundary for where traditional search still wins (local, intent-to-act queries) versus AI answer engines.

quotes.topic_title: Structured vs unstructured answers and SEO disruption
quotes.text: Well, I just thought that was interesting to really drill into the difference between structured and unstructured, because unstructured is actually where Google is disrupting everything.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing: the real threat isn’t old-school structured snippets, but AI transforming unstructured content into answers.

quotes.topic_title: Structured vs unstructured answers and SEO disruption
quotes.text: So this entire idea of SEO, again, up until 2022 was monetize unstructured data. Whoever wrote the longest piece of content on best beach hotels in Miami and then built the best links to it, they would win.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Summarizes the pre-AI SEO playbook and why it’s vulnerable now—useful for diagnosing which strategies are becoming obsolete.

quotes.topic_title: Top vs mid vs bottom funnel search examples
quotes.text: So you would get back a list from G2, which would give you out all the software.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Concrete top-of-funnel example (podcasting tools) showing how listicle/comparison aggregators have historically captured discovery searches.

quotes.topic_title: Top vs mid vs bottom funnel search examples
quotes.text: And that's when you start doing those searches. Now you're mid-funnel. Now let's say you've chosen Riverside and you've gotten enough information from those other searches. Now you start searching Riverside price, Riverside capacity, Riverside bandwidth.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Clear mid-funnel/bottom-funnel query pattern practitioners can target (pricing/capability intent) once users have narrowed options.

quotes.topic_title: Top vs mid vs bottom funnel search examples
quotes.text: But now that doesn't exist anymore. You just go to Google and Google tells you, "These are the tools. Oh, you're looking for a new CRM? This is what a CRM is. You want to know, do you need a CRM or do you just need a calendar?"
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Counterintuitive shift: AI answers absorb broad comparison/definition queries, pushing SEO opportunity away from top-of-funnel content.

quotes.topic_title: Top vs mid vs bottom funnel search examples
quotes.text: So I think that's where SEO always should have been because that's where conversions could potentially happen.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to prioritize mid/bottom-funnel intent where conversion likelihood is highest.

quotes.topic_title: Top vs mid vs bottom funnel search examples
quotes.text: However, SEO never was there before because the way most SEO measures its performance and its success is rankings.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Memorable critique of the rankings-first metric trap that can misalign SEO work with business outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: What to do now: treat SEO as product
quotes.text: I think of SEO as a product. And I think the product managers are the people that should be thinking about this SEO question because it's a product question. There are users that are coming in from the search channel. What is the product that I need to create for them?
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Reframes SEO from a marketing tactic into a product responsibility centered on designing for search-driven users.

quotes.topic_title: What to do now: treat SEO as product
quotes.text: So typically, it was thought of as a marketing challenge of the product people have created this thing for me, and now I expect the marketers to go and do the SEO thing for it. But there's a mismatch.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Highlights the common failure mode where marketing is asked to “SEO” a product that wasn’t built for search intent.

quotes.topic_title: What to do now: treat SEO as product
quotes.text: So for example, I find very often when I talk to SaaS companies, I don't think SaaS in general should do SEO.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A provocative claim that challenges the default assumption that SEO is universally a good growth channel for SaaS.

quotes.topic_title: What to do now: treat SEO as product
quotes.text: So that's what everyone should be doing, product really collaborating with marketing and discovering what is it that the user wants and showcasing that.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: align product + marketing around real user intent and demonstrate it clearly in search journeys.

quotes.topic_title: What to do now: treat SEO as product
quotes.text: They wrote thousands of blog posts about health in general. I told them they shouldn't do that in general, but they wanted me to experience their product. So they gave me a code to download their app, and their app is awful. It's a bad product.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Concrete example showing that scaling content (even with AI) can’t compensate for a weak product experience.

quotes.topic_title: Zapier case study: programmatic integration pages
quotes.text: They were doing something that no one needed. They had this product which zapped things together, but no one needed it because they didn't know it existed. But people knew that they needed things to work together.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Highlights the core demand-discovery gap: users don’t search for your product, they search for the outcome they need.

quotes.topic_title: Zapier case study: programmatic integration pages
quotes.text: They just weren't looking for Zapier.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A succinct reminder to target existing search intent rather than forcing brand/product-term demand.

quotes.topic_title: Zapier case study: programmatic integration pages
quotes.text: So what if we created as a product a marketing way to showcase that this product of zapping Gmail to Salesforce and Salesforce to Gmail exists?
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A practical methodology: turn “use-case discovery” into a scalable marketing surface that functions like a product.

quotes.topic_title: Zapier case study: programmatic integration pages
quotes.text: So we built that at scale for everything that could work, and that was the experiment that I did with them, where everything would be available and it creates this flywheel of, wow, if Gmail can work with Salesforce, what else does Gmail work with?
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Describes the programmatic SEO play and the flywheel mechanism that drives compounding discovery across integrations.

quotes.topic_title: Zapier case study: programmatic integration pages
quotes.text: people are looking for that other thing that you could do, showcase the fact that your product could do this thing.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for SEO/content: map pages to adjacent user intents (“the other thing”) and demonstrate capability.

quotes.topic_title: Tinder case study: local intent and loneliness problem
quotes.text: One of the biggest challenges I ever had with SEO, especially as a consultant, is getting things done.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Highlights the often-overlooked execution/resourcing bottleneck that determines whether SEO strategy turns into impact.

quotes.topic_title: Tinder case study: local intent and loneliness problem
quotes.text: So when we started working together, the first thing we came up with is what is someone going to be searching when they look for Tinder?
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A practical starting framework for SEO: begin with real user search intent rather than generic keyword lists.

quotes.topic_title: Tinder case study: local intent and loneliness problem
quotes.text: But in our user research and in the discussions we had on what the investment we can make into SEO was we discovered that Tinder is a loneliness-solving problem, loneliness-solving solution.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Reframes SEO around the true job-to-be-done, guiding what content/pages to build and why they convert.

quotes.topic_title: Tinder case study: local intent and loneliness problem
quotes.text: Actually nothing changes here with AiO reviews because if you're looking for, you've gone to Dubai. You've just... You've gone to Dubai. It's a brand new country, you've never been there before, and you're lonely.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A counterintuitive claim that AI Overviews don’t eliminate demand when the query reflects a high-intent, real-world problem.

quotes.topic_title: Tinder case study: local intent and loneliness problem
quotes.text: So that's where I think SEO should be is you need to be in the buyer journey with the SEO you're creating.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to align SEO assets to funnel stage and user journey rather than producing broad top-of-funnel content.

quotes.topic_title: Practical steps to start SEO in AI era
quotes.text: I think step one is the step that almost everyone misses on SEO, which is be the user. Try to understand who your user is.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A simple but often-missed starting point: SEO begins with customer empathy, not keywords or tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Practical steps to start SEO in AI era
quotes.text: So if you can't answer the question about what is it that someone's going to do a search on, then don't do SEO because SEO is about appealing to that user.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A contrarian filter for whether SEO is even worth doing: if you can’t name the search intent, stop.

quotes.topic_title: Practical steps to start SEO in AI era
quotes.text: We know we want to be programmatic because no one wants to in position of writing a page out for every town or every city or every neighborhood in the entire world.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A practical methodology choice: scale SEO by building programmatic assets instead of manual editorial pages.

quotes.topic_title: Practical steps to start SEO in AI era
quotes.text: I think of it as a product, which means you need design resources. You need engineering resources. Of course, you need a product manager to really oversee the building of this. You need user research.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Reframes SEO as product development, clarifying the cross-functional resources required to win.

quotes.topic_title: Practical steps to start SEO in AI era
quotes.text: So I think there's a really powerful point here that might be... people might not get, which is the user needs to be thinking of something they will go to Google to search for to find your product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A crisp test for SEO viability: your product must map to a real, Google-searchable user thought/problem.

quotes.topic_title: When SEO is a bad fit for SaaS
quotes.text: So it's if they're... if nobody is searching for the thing that you're building in some way, there's not going to be an opportunity for you to win an SEO or and benefit from SEO.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A simple litmus test for whether SEO can work at all: demand must already exist in search behavior.

quotes.topic_title: When SEO is a bad fit for SaaS
quotes.text: We came up with the content. We built the links. We did all the stuff SEO was supposed to do, and it didn't work.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A concrete example (Mixpanel) showing that “doing SEO right” can still fail when the business model/journey doesn’t support conversion.

quotes.topic_title: When SEO is a bad fit for SaaS
quotes.text: Mixpanel is a product you integrate in your entire company. You don't just do a quick Google for it and be like, "Oh, analytics. Yeah. I'm going to tell everyone we got to do it and it's going to be live tomorrow."
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Highlights how implementation complexity and organizational rollout break the typical search-to-purchase funnel.

quotes.topic_title: When SEO is a bad fit for SaaS
quotes.text: So I had another eye-opening experience early in COVID when I was... everyone was home, and there wasn't a lot of things to do. Google reached out to me about a role on their team on Google Cloud for doing SEO.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Sets up a high-profile case study (Google Cloud) to examine when SEO doesn’t make strategic sense even for top brands.

quotes.topic_title: When SEO is a bad fit for SaaS
quotes.text: So SEO sort of made no sense for that even to be included as a part of a marketing channel.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A blunt, counterintuitive takeaway: in committee-driven, long-cycle purchases, SEO may be structurally misaligned as a channel.

quotes.topic_title: How to evaluate SEO ROI and tradeoffs
quotes.text: So we have to really put away the myth that SEO is free because it's absolutely not free.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Reframes SEO as a real, fully-loaded investment decision rather than a default “free” channel.

quotes.topic_title: How to evaluate SEO ROI and tradeoffs
quotes.text: So it's $10,000 a month, $120,000 a year, gets even more expensive if you have a full-time employee.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Gives a concrete baseline cost for SEO resourcing that teams can use in ROI calculations.

quotes.topic_title: How to evaluate SEO ROI and tradeoffs
quotes.text: Or if they took that exact same million dollars and put it into brand ads, or they put it into influencer campaigns, or they put it into just traditional paid marketing on Meta and Google, would you make that million dollars or $1,000,001 back faster?
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: Introduces a tradeoff-based ROI test: compare SEO against alternative channels on payback speed.

quotes.topic_title: How to evaluate SEO ROI and tradeoffs
quotes.text: Instead of spending $15,000 on SEO, you can get... you can go to all these shows for the exact same budget, and you get users who are interested, they're in market, they try your tool out at the booth, and then they leave and they're leads that you could follow up with.
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A vivid example of reallocating SEO budget to a higher-intent acquisition channel when the audience isn’t primarily online-search driven.

quotes.topic_title: How to evaluate SEO ROI and tradeoffs
quotes.text: Again, from a product standpoint, there's always trade-offs. So what are the trade-offs to investing in this channel versus another channel?
quotes.speaker: Eli Schwartz
quotes.context: A portable decision-making lens: treat channel strategy like product prioritization with explicit opportunity costs.
